/* Definitions and scope of the word */

Make religion section separate, instead of subsection of dif. between Nazism and Fascism
Delete duplicate section on religion. This section is almost entirely unsourced, has OR, SYN and POV problems. Religion section earlier in the article is well sourced and covers the subject.
/* Religion */ Additional sourcing, nuance, various positions of different fascist movements, cites.
Delete factual error. Hitler was an apostate who renounced the church at the age of twelve. Mussolini was originally quite anti-Catholic and only made accomodations due to popular attitudes.
/* Fascism and the Roman Catholic Church */ citation needed

seriously, who's gonna type "Fascist" when looking for the Indian name [[Vashisht]]?
/* See also */ Islamofascism is a controversial idea which is largely just an epithet against authoritarian Islamist regimes, rather than any real ideology.
/* See also */ Nasserism is not fascism, it had links to Tito's communist regime in Yugoslavia and the Soviet Union

[[WP:UNDO|Undid]] revision 207505818 by [[Special:Contributions/Cberlet|Cberlet]] ([[User talk:Cberlet|talk]]) Undoing Cberlet trying to override majority view.
Revert: outdated, not accurate, too narrow, against majority view
it is defined that way by the sources I cited; see talk; we should keep the intro short and to the point, but I have added a mention of race in the definition
This is from further down in the article and is probably good to place here.
No, it is not defined that way by the source and for good reason. Fascism can place the race as the most important interest.
"placing the nation above all other sources of loyalty" is more inclusive, because fascism subordinates not only individual interests but also class interests to the nation (source: Passmore)
this is implied by their opposition to liberalism

/* Definitions and scope of the word */
"individual interests would be subordinated to the good of the nation" from Encyclopedia Britannica article
attempted to build a better definition from sources; see Talk
/* Definitions and scope of the word */
/* Fascism and religion */ Nazism and religion has been moved to [[Religion in Nazi Germany]]
If you cannot cite the page of the cited author's book on which your claims are validated, you have no business changing the lead
and it's not just the individual that gets subordinated
Cleared up confusing sentence structures in the 'Differences and similarities with Nazism' section.
Cberlet, the previous first sentence could define *any* authoritarian movement; let's at least make it nation-state
the nation-state (and sometimes the race) is seen as paramount
/* Differences and similarities with Nazism */ Mussolini said this in 1932, the book with the conversation was published in 1933
